NEU215.name: Neuroscience and Society
NEU215.description: Critical examination of important societal issues related to neuroscience, including stress, addiction, and sex differences. Comparison of peer-reviewed neuroscientific research and popular press publications.
NEU215.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

NEU230.name: Basic Concepts in Neuroscience
NEU230.description: Introduction to fundamental neuroscience concepts including neuroanatomy, neuronal signaling, and molecular mechanisms of learning and memory.
NEU230.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement

NEU300.name: Neurobiology
NEU300.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
NEU300.description: Structure and function of nerve cells and nervous systems.
NEU300.prerequisite: (BS 162 or LB 144 or BS 182H) and (BS 161 or LB 145 or BS 181H)
NEU300.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores and not open to students in the Program in Neuroscience and not open to students in the Lyman Briggs Neuroscience Major.

NEU301.name: Introduction to Neuroscience I
NEU301.description: Survey of the field of neuroscience, including molecular, cellular, and autonomic, sensory and motor systems.
NEU301.prerequisite: (BS 161 or BS 181H or LB 145) and (BS 162 or BS 182H or LB 144)
NEU301.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Program in Neuroscience or in the Lyman Briggs Neuroscience Coordinate Major.

NEU302.name: Introduction to Neuroscience II
NEU302.description: Survey of brain-based behavioral and cognitive systems and related human diseases.
NEU302.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Lyman Briggs College or in the College of Natural Science or in the Program in Neuroscience.

NEU304.name: Neuroanatomy
NEU304.description: Structure and basic function of human nervous system, including the influence of art and cultural values on neuroanatomical knowledge throughout history.
NEU304.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
NEU304.restrictions: Not open to freshmen. Approval of department; application required.

NEU306.name: History of Neuroscience
NEU306.description: Specific topics in the history of neuroscience with an emphasis on the influence of cultural values on theories and discoveries.
NEU306.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
NEU306.restrictions: Not open to freshmen. Approval of department; application required.

NEU307.name: Topics in History of Neuroscience (W)
NEU307.description: Independent library research and group tutorial work aimed at critical analysis of the role that cultural values and historical events played in the specific topic investigated.
NEU307.prerequisite: Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
NEU307.restrictions: Not open to freshmen. Approval of department; application required.

NEU310.name: Psychology and Biology of Human Sexuality
NEU310.description: Sexual behavior from biological, psychological and neuroscience perspectives. Sexual differentiation of the body. Role of hormones in development and reproduction in humans and other animals. Human sexual orientation. Fertility and contraception. Sexual disorders. Sexually transmitted diseases.
NEU310.prerequisite: (PSY 101 or concurrently) and ((BS 161 or concurrently) or (BS 162 or concurrently) or (LB 144 or concurrently) or (LB 145 or concurrently) or (BS 181H or concurrently) or (BS 182H or concurrently))

NEU311L.name: Neuroscience Laboratory (W)
NEU311L.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
NEU311L.description: Overview of neuroscience research methodology, including experimental design, data analysis, and presentation of results.
NEU311L.prerequisite: ((NEU 301 or concurrently) and completion of Tier I writing requirement) and (STT 201 or STT 231 or STT 421) and (BS 171 or BS 191H or LB 145)
NEU311L.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Program in Neuroscience or in the Lyman Briggs Neuroscience Coordinate Major.

NEU333.name: The Neurobiology of Food Intake and Overeating
NEU333.description: Physiological and neurological mechanisms that drive food intake and overeating. Vulnerabilities to obesity.

NEU415.name: Neuroinformatics and Quantitative Reasoning
NEU415.description: Quantitative reasoning and statistical methods for querying internet databases and understanding basic neuroscience models
NEU415.prerequisite: ((NEU 301 and (NEU 302 or concurrently)) and completion of Tier I writing requirement) and (MTH 124 or MTH 132 or MTH 152H or LB 118) and (STT 201 or STT 231 or STT 421 or PSY 295)
NEU415.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Neuroscience Major or in the Lyman Briggs Neuroscience Coordinate Major.

NEU416.name: Development of the Nervous System Through the Lifespan
NEU416.description: Development of neurons and their connections, roles of both genetics and behavioral experience in shaping the mammalian nervous system.
NEU416.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Program in Neuroscience or in the Department of Integrative Biology or in the Department of Psychology or in the Lyman Briggs Neuroscience Major or in the Lyman Briggs Zoology Coordinate Major.

NEU417.name: Instrumental Methods of Analysis in Neuroscience
NEU417.description: Design, operational principles and practical application of modern instrumental methods used for the separation, identification and quantification of neurochemical species in neuroscience. Application of methods of chemical analysis to study neurosignaling, chemical composition in single secretory cells, chemical structure of cells and tissues.
NEU417.prerequisite: {{(CEM 251 and CEM 252) or (CEM 351 and CEM 352)} and (PHY 231 and PHY 232)} or (PHY 183 and PHY 184) or (PHY 193H and PHY 294H) or (LB 273 and LB 274)

NEU420.name: Neurobiology of Disease
NEU420.description: Genetic, molecular, cellular, systems, and behavioral abnormalities that contribute to the manifestation of neurologic and psychiatric diseases and disorders that affect the nervous system.
NEU420.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Program in Neuroscience or in the Lyman Briggs Neuroscience Coordinate Major.

NEU422.name: Fundamentals of Neuropharmacology
NEU422.description: Mechanisms and uses of action of drugs on neurons and neuron-controlled activities
NEU422.prerequisite: NEU 301 or PSL 250 or PSL 310 or PSL 431
NEU422.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or approval of department.

NEU425.name: Computational Modeling in Neuroscience
NEU425.description: Introduction to theory and network modeling techniques in neuroscience, using brain activity data to validate theoretical models. Review of successful network models.
NEU425.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Neuroscience Major or in the Lyman Briggs Neuroscience Major.

NEU430.name: Genomics of Brain Development, Learning, and Behavior
NEU430.description: Role of genes in brain development and function. Issues in behavioral and psychiatric genetics.

NEU431.name: Pharmacology of Drug Addiction
NEU431.description: Introduction to pharmacology and neuropharmacology. Understanding of the biological basis for drug abuse and addiction.

NEU435.name: Ion Channels of Excitable Membranes
NEU435.description: Introduction to ion channels and their critical role in normal physiological functioning, sensory and neuromuscular diseases and disorders, as well as targets of toxins and poisons.
NEU435.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Neuroscience Major or in the Bachelor of Science in Zoology or in the Lyman Briggs Neuroscience Major or in the Lyman Briggs Zoology Coordinate Major.

NEU440.name: Synaptic Transmission
NEU440.description: Chemical and electrical aspects of nerve impulse transmission at synaptic and neuroeffector junctions. Influence of drugs.
NEU440.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Neuroscience Major or in the Lyman Briggs Neuroscience Major.

NEU445.name: Analysis of Neural Activity Data (W)
NEU445.description: Conceptual and practical approaches to analyzing large functional datasets. Emphasis on statistical issues, including preprocessing, estimation methods, hypothesis testing, dimension reduction, and correlation with behavior. Data types include electrophysiological recording, electroencephalography (EEG), magnetoencephalography (MEG), functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) and optical imaging.
NEU445.prerequisite: ((NEU 301 and (NEU 302 or concurrently)) and completion of Tier I writing requirement) and (MTH 124 or MTH 132 or MTH 152H or LB 118) and (STT 201 or STT 231 or STT 421 or PSY 295)

NEU490.name: Special Problems in Neuroscience
NEU490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
NEU490.description: Students work under the direction of a faculty member on a selected research problem.
NEU490.prerequisite: (PSY 101 and NEU 301) and (STT 201 or STT 231 or STT 421)
NEU490.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors. Approval of department. A student may earn a maximum of 15 credits A student may earn a maximum of 15 credits in NEU 490 and NEU 492.

NEU492.name: Special Topics in Neuroscience
NEU492.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
NEU492.description: Current topics proposed by faculty that supplement regular course offerings.
NEU492.restrictions: Open to sophomores or juniors or seniors in the Neuroscience Major or in the Lyman Briggs Neuroscience Coordinate Major. Approval of department. A student may earn a maximum of 15 credits in NEU 490 and NEU 492.

NEU499.name: Neuroscience Senior Research Thesis
NEU499.description: Independent research mentored by a neuroscience faculty member and conducted in their laboratory.
NEU499.prerequisite: (NEU 490) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
NEU499.restrictions: Open to seniors in the Neuroscience Major. Approval of department.

NEU800.name: Neuroscience Research Forum
NEU800.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
NEU800.description: Readings, presentations, and discussions of research literature in neuroscience. Professional development.

NEU801.name: Molecular, Cellular and Developmental Neuroscience I
NEU801.description: Genetics, molecular and cellular biology of the developing and the adult nervous system.
NEU801.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Natural Science or in the Program in Neuroscience or in the Neuroscience-Environmental Toxicology Major. Approval of department.

NEU802.name: Systems and Behavioral Neuroscience I
NEU802.description: Anatomy and physiology of multicellular neural systems controlling learning and memory, motivated behaviors, pain, biological rhythms and psychopathologies.
NEU802.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Program in Neuroscience. Approval of department.

NEU803.name: Molecular, Cellular and Developmental Neuroscience II
NEU803.description: Electrical and intra- and extracellular signaling mechanisms of neurons and glia in health and disease in the developing and mature nervous system.
NEU803.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Program in Neuroscience. Approval of department.

NEU804.name: Molecular and Developmental Neurobiology
NEU804.description: Nervous system specific gene transcription and translation. Maturation, degeneration, plasticity, and repair in the nervous system.
NEU804.restrictions: Open to graduate students in Neuroscience major.

NEU805.name: Systems and Behavioral Neuroscience II
NEU805.description: Anatomy and physiology of multicellular olfactory, visual, auditory, motor, somatosensory and autonomic nervous systems.
NEU805.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Program in Neuroscience or in the Neuroscience-Environmental Toxicology Major. Approval of department.

NEU807.name: Strategies in Neuroscience Research
NEU807.description: Methods and underlying principles of neuroscience research.
NEU807.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Neuroscience Major.

NEU811.name: Advanced Behavioral Neuroscience
NEU811.description: Biological mechanisms involved in learning and memory, motivated behaviors, biological rhythms, and psychopathologies.
NEU811.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Psychology major or Neuroscience major.

NEU815.name: Neuroinformatics and Quantitative Reasoning
NEU815.description: Quantitative reasoning and statistical methods for querying internet databases and understanding basic neuroscience models for graduate students
NEU815.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Medical Neuroscience Graduate Certificate or in the Neuroscience Major or in the Neuroscience-Environmental Toxicology Major. Approval of department.

NEU827.name: Physiology and Pharmacology of Excitable Cells
NEU827.description: Function of neurons and muscle at the cellular level
NEU827.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Natural Science or in the Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology or approval of department.

NEU832.name: Evolution of Nervous Systems
NEU832.description: Evolutionary origins, mechanisms, and consequences of evolutionary change in nervous systems.
NEU832.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering or in the Department of Integrative Biology or in the Program in Neuroscience or in the Department of Psychology or approval of department.

NEU839.name: Systems Neuroscience
NEU839.description: Anatomy, pharmacology, and physiology of multicellular neural systems. Sensory, motor, autonomic, and chemo-regulatory systems in vertebrate brains.
NEU839.restrictions: Open to graduate students or human medicine students or osteopathic medicine students in the College of Natural Science or in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources or in the College of Human Medicine or in the College of Osteopathic Medicine or in the College of Social Science or in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

NEU840.name: Social, Cognitive, and Affective Neuroscience
NEU840.description: Introduction to nervous system structure and function aimed at students and professionals with limited biological science background.

NEU841.name: Medical Neuroscience
NEU841.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
NEU841.description: Detailed survey of nervous system structure and function with an emphasis on medical applications.
NEU841.restrictions: Not open to doctoral students in the Program in Neuroscience.

NEU842.name: Neuroethics
NEU842.description: Introduction to the field of neuroethics and the responsible application of advances in neuroscience research.

NEU843.name: Methods for Assessing the Nervous System
NEU843.description: Introduction to the various techniques and methods used to study brain structure and function.

NEU844.name: The Science and Ethics of Brain Interventions
NEU844.description: Introduction to cognitive enhancement to improve intellect and cognition, and legal and ethical implications of this.

NEU845.name: Neuroscience of Drug Use and Human Disorders
NEU845.description: Introduction to the neurochemical basis of human disorders and how drugs are used to treat these disorders.

NEU846.name: Neurobiology of Nervous System Disorders
NEU846.description: Overview of abnormalities that contribute to central nervous system, peripheral nervous system, and psychological diseases and disorders examined at genetic, cellular, and behavioral levels.
NEU846.restrictions: Not open to doctoral students in the Program in Neuroscience.

NEU847.name: Development of the Nervous System
NEU847.description: Introduction to processes involved in the development of the nervous systems and their clinical application.

NEU848.name: Foundations of Law and Legal Research
NEU848.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
NEU848.description: Introduction to the American legal system with focus on legal research and communication needs of non-lawyers
NEU848.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Program in Neuroscience. Approval of department.

NEU890.name: Independent Study in Neuroscience
NEU890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
NEU890.description: Supervised student research on a specialized research topic in basic or clinical neuroscience.

NEU892.name: Special Topics in Neuroscience and the Law
NEU892.description: Topics in which the field of neuroscience and the legal system intersect

NEU899.name: Master's Thesis Research
NEU899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

NEU992.name: Advanced Topics in Neuroscience
NEU992.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
NEU992.description: Readings, presentations and discussion of specialized topics in neuroscience.

NEU999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
NEU999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
